title: In what order should one read Plato’s works? - Quora

response.answer_text: The usual way to start is with the trilogy on the death of Socrates: Apology; Crito; Phaedo. The first will give you a vivid idea of the conflict between democracy and philosophy; the second will establish that social contract theory is a very old idea; the third will present the Platonic case for soul/body dualism and the immortality of the former. The trilogy is, it seems to me, a fine way to start. Beyond that, here’s another trilogy: The Republic; Protagoras; Parmenides. When you’ve read all this, you’ll have a sound grounding and you can let your own curiosity (and the secondary works you will by then want to read) take you from there. Enjoy the trip.

Most of his writings are not in any chronological order so there is not any actual required order. I myself starting reading his works somewhat out of order and have noticed you’re left wondering what some of the terms mean if you weren’t previously exposed; don’t start with Laws is my point. I myself started with the Republic and then went to Laws after that read Statemen and then Sophist. I will begin after I finish the book I am currently reading an anthology released through Penguin Classics of his early writings titled “The Last Days of Socrates” which includes Euthypro, Apology, Crito, and Phaedo. I guess that would put me just about half way through his works and almost completely through his major works.
